title: Ray Cheney
text:
Ray Cheney is a retired <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player and sportsman from <a href="Wales">Wales</a>.
Early years.
Ray was born in <a href="Porth">Porth</a> in the <a href="Rhondda">Rhondda</a>. He showed exceptional all round sporting abilities and played <a href="association%20football">football</a> at <a href="Ton%20Pentre">Ton Pentre</a> for <a href="Ton%20Pentre%20F.C.">Ton Pentre F.C.</a>. He also played Welsh Youth <a href="soccer">soccer</a>, winning an international youth cap at <a href="centre%20forward">centre forward</a> and attracted the attention of <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20FC">Tottenham Hotspur FC</a>.
<a href="National%20Service">National Service</a> was spent in the <a href="RAF">RAF</a>, where he was able to represent the RAF at rugby.
Rugby career.
On return to civilian life Ray joined <a href="Pontypool%20RFC">Pontypool RFC</a> in <a href="Monmouthshire">Monmouthshire</a>, setting a club record at the time of 169 points and playing against a touring <a href="South%20Africa%20rugby%20union%20team">Springboks</a> and maintained a position within the Welsh Reserves.
Moving to local rivals <a href="Newport%20RFC">Newport RFC</a> during the 1962/3 season and making his club debut against <a href="Llanelli%20RFC">Llanelli RFC</a> in March '63 he was soon scoring heavily again and amassed 40 points in 11 games. The visiting 1963 <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">All Blacks</a> side was beaten by Newport with Ray hitting the cross bar with an attempted <a href="drop%20goal">drop goal</a>. By the end of his first full season at the club Ray again set a club record, amassing 171 points during the 63/4 season. In the 64/5 season he surpassed that, attaining 224 points, passing his century in just 15 games.
Ray developed a 'round the corner' deadball kicking style for <a href="place%20kick">place kick</a>s, one of the pioneers of this new style at the time.
Ray was in the Welsh Reserves, at <a href="full%20back%20%28rugby%20union%29">full back</a>, some 23 times.
He joined <a href="Cardiff%20RFC">Cardiff RFC</a>, running out 69 times and playing in the side that beat <a href="Australian%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> in 1966.
He also represented both <a href="Crawshays%20RFC">Crawshays RFC</a> and Monmouthshire.
He also played <a href="cricket">cricket</a> for <a href="Monmouthshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Monmouthshire County Cricket Club</a>.
